ex2p.cpp
00001 //                       MFEM Example 2 - Parallel Version
00002 //
00003 // Compile with: make ex2p
00004 //
00005 // Sample runs:  mpirun -np 4 ex2p ../data/beam-tri.mesh
00006 //               mpirun -np 4 ex2p ../data/beam-quad.mesh
00007 //               mpirun -np 4 ex2p ../data/beam-tet.mesh
00008 //               mpirun -np 4 ex2p ../data/beam-hex.mesh
00009 //
00010 // Description:  This example code solves a simple linear elasticity problem
00011 //               describing a multi-material Cantilever beam.
00012 //
00013 //               Specifically, we approximate the weak form of -div(sigma(u))=0
00014 //               where sigma(u)=lambda*div(u)*I+mu*(grad*u+u*grad) is the stress
00015 //               tensor corresponding to displacement field u, and lambda and mu
00016 //               are the material Lame constants. The boundary conditions are
00017 //               u=0 on the fixed part of the boundary with attribute 1, and
00018 //               sigma(u).n=f on the remainder with f being a constant pull down
00019 //               vector on boundary elements with attribute 2, and zero
00020 //               otherwise. The geometry of the domain is assumed to be as
00021 //               follows:
00022 //
00023 //                                 +----------+----------+
00024 //                    boundary --->| material | material |<--- boundary
00025 //                    attribute 1  |    1     |    2     |     attribute 2
00026 //                    (fixed)      +----------+----------+     (pull down)
00027 //
00028 //               The example demonstrates the use of (high-order) vector finite
00029 //               element spaces with the linear elasticity bilinear form, meshes
00030 //               with curved elements, and the definition of piece-wise constant
00031 //               and vector coefficient objects.
00032 //
00033 //               We recommend viewing example 1 before viewing this example.
00034 
00035 #include <fstream>
00036 #include "mfem.hpp"
00037 
00038 int main (int argc, char *argv[])
00039 {
00040    int num_procs, myid;
00041 
00042    // 1. Initialize MPI
00043    MPI_Init(&argc, &argv);
00044    MPI_Comm_size(MPI_COMM_WORLD, &num_procs);
00045    MPI_Comm_rank(MPI_COMM_WORLD, &myid);
00046 
00047    Mesh *mesh;
00048 
00049    if (argc == 1)
00050    {
00051       if (myid == 0)
00052          cout << "\nUsage: mpirun -np <np> ex2p <mesh_file>\n" << endl;
00053       MPI_Finalize();
00054       return 1;
00055    }
00056 
00057    // 2. Read the (serial) mesh from the given mesh file on all processors.
00058    //    We can handle triangular, quadrilateral, tetrahedral or hexahedral
00059    //    elements with the same code.
00060    ifstream imesh(argv[1]);
00061    if (!imesh)
00062    {
00063       if (myid == 0)
00064          cerr << "\nCan not open mesh file: " << argv[1] << '\n' << endl;
00065       MPI_Finalize();
00066       return 2;
00067    }
00068    mesh = new Mesh(imesh, 1, 1);
00069    imesh.close();
00070 
00071    if (mesh->attributes.Max() < 2 || mesh->bdr_attributes.Max() < 2)
00072    {
00073       if (myid == 0)
00074          cerr << "\nInput mesh should have at least two materials and "
00075               << "two boundary attributes! (See schematic in ex2.cpp)\n"
00076               << endl;
00077       MPI_Finalize();
00078       return 3;
00079    }
00080    int dim = mesh->Dimension();
00081 
00082    // 3. Refine the serial mesh on all processors to increase the resolution. In
00083    //    this example we do 'ref_levels' of uniform refinement. We choose
00084    //    'ref_levels' to be the largest number that gives a final mesh with no
00085    //    more than 1,000 elements.
00086    {
00087       int ref_levels =
00088          (int)floor(log(1000./mesh->GetNE())/log(2.)/dim);
00089       for (int l = 0; l < ref_levels; l++)
00090          mesh->UniformRefinement();
00091    }
00092 
00093    // 4. Define a parallel mesh by a partitioning of the serial mesh. Refine
00094    //    this mesh further in parallel to increase the resolution. Once the
00095    //    parallel mesh is defined, the serial mesh can be deleted.
00096    ParMesh *pmesh = new ParMesh(MPI_COMM_WORLD, *mesh);
00097    delete mesh;
00098    {
00099       int par_ref_levels = 1;
00100       for (int l = 0; l < par_ref_levels; l++)
00101          pmesh->UniformRefinement();
00102    }
00103 
00104    // 5. Define a parallel finite element space on the parallel mesh. Here we
00105    //    use vector finite elements, i.e. dim copies of a scalar finite element
00106    //    space. We use the ordering by vector dimension (the last argument of
00107    //    the FiniteElementSpace constructor) which is expected in the systems
00108    //    version of BoomerAMG preconditioner.
00109    FiniteElementCollection *fec;
00110    int fec_type;
00111    if (myid == 0)
00112    {
00113       cout << "Choose the finite element space:\n"
00114            << " 1) Linear\n"
00115            << " 2) Quadratic\n"
00116            << " 3) Cubic\n"
00117            << " ---> ";
00118       cin >> fec_type;
00119    }
00120    MPI_Bcast(&fec_type, 1, MPI_INT, 0, MPI_COMM_WORLD);
00121    switch (fec_type)
00122    {
00123    default:
00124    case 1:
00125       fec = new LinearFECollection; break;
00126    case 2:
00127       fec = new QuadraticFECollection; break;
00128    case 3:
00129       fec = new CubicFECollection; break;
00130    }
00131    if (myid == 0)
00132       cout << "Assembling: " << flush;
00133    ParFiniteElementSpace *fespace =
00134       new ParFiniteElementSpace(pmesh, fec, dim, Ordering::byVDIM);
00135 
00136    // 6. Set up the parallel linear form b(.) which corresponds to the
00137    //    right-hand side of the FEM linear system. In this case, b_i equals the
00138    //    boundary integral of f*phi_i where f represents a "pull down" force on
00139    //    the Neumann part of the boundary and phi_i are the basis functions in
00140    //    the finite element fespace. The force is defined by the object f, which
00141    //    is a vector of Coefficient objects. The fact that f is non-zero on
00142    //    boundary attribute 2 is indicated by the use of piece-wise constants
00143    //    coefficient for its last component.
00144    VectorArrayCoefficient f(dim);
00145    for (int i = 0; i < dim-1; i++)
00146       f.Set(i, new ConstantCoefficient(0.0));
00147    {
00148       Vector pull_force(pmesh->bdr_attributes.Max());
00149       pull_force = 0.0;
00150       pull_force(1) = -1.0e-2;
00151       f.Set(dim-1, new PWConstCoefficient(pull_force));
00152    }
00153 
00154    ParLinearForm *b = new ParLinearForm(fespace);
00155    b->AddDomainIntegrator(new VectorBoundaryLFIntegrator(f));
00156    if (myid == 0)
00157       cout << "r.h.s. ... " << flush;
00158    b->Assemble();
00159 
00160    // 7. Define the solution vector x as a parallel finite element grid function
00161    //    corresponding to fespace. Initialize x with initial guess of zero,
00162    //    which satisfies the boundary conditions.
00163    ParGridFunction x(fespace);
00164    (Vector &)x = 0.0;
00165 
00166    // 8. Set up the parallel bilinear form a(.,.) on the finite element space
00167    //    corresponding to the linear elasticity integrator with piece-wise
00168    //    constants coefficient lambda and mu. The boundary conditions are
00169    //    implemented by marking only boundary attribute 1 as essential. After
00170    //    serial/parallel assembly we extract the corresponding parallel matrix.
00171    Vector lambda(pmesh->attributes.Max());
00172    lambda = 1.0;
00173    lambda(0) = lambda(1)*50;
00174    PWConstCoefficient lambda_func(lambda);
00175    Vector mu(pmesh->attributes.Max());
00176    mu = 1.0;
00177    mu(0) = mu(1)*50;
00178    PWConstCoefficient mu_func(mu);
00179 
00180    ParBilinearForm *a = new ParBilinearForm(fespace);
00181    a->AddDomainIntegrator(new ElasticityIntegrator(lambda_func, mu_func));
00182    if (myid == 0)
00183       cout << "matrix ... " << flush;
00184    a->Assemble();
00185    {
00186       Array<int> ess_bdr(pmesh->bdr_attributes.Max());
00187       ess_bdr = 0;
00188       ess_bdr[0] = 1;
00189       Array<int> ess_dofs;
00190       fespace->GetEssentialVDofs(ess_bdr, ess_dofs);
00191       a->EliminateEssentialBCFromDofs(ess_dofs, x, *b);
00192    }
00193    a->Finalize();
00194    if (myid == 0)
00195       cout << "done." << endl;
00196 
00197    // 9. Define the parallel (hypre) matrix and vectors representing a(.,.),
00198    //    b(.) and the finite element approximation.
00199    HypreParMatrix *A = a->ParallelAssemble();
00200    HypreParVector *B = b->ParallelAssemble();
00201    HypreParVector *X = x.ParallelAverage();
00202 
00203    delete a;
00204    delete b;
00205 
00206    // 10. Define and apply a parallel PCG solver for AX=B with the BoomerAMG
00207    //     preconditioner from hypre.
00208    HypreBoomerAMG *amg = new HypreBoomerAMG(*A);
00209    amg->SetSystemsOptions(dim);
00210    HyprePCG *pcg = new HyprePCG(*A);
00211    pcg->SetTol(1e-8);
00212    pcg->SetMaxIter(500);
00213    pcg->SetPrintLevel(2);
00214    pcg->SetPreconditioner(*amg);
00215    pcg->Mult(*B, *X);
00216 
00217    // 11. Extract the parallel grid function corresponding to the finite element
00218    //     approximation X. This is the local solution on each processor.
00219    x = *X;
00220 
00221    // 12. Make the mesh curved based on the finite element space. This means
00222    //     that we define the mesh elements through a fespace-based
00223    //     transformation of the reference element.  This allows us to save the
00224    //     displaced mesh as a curved mesh when using high-order finite element
00225    //     displacement field. We assume that the initial mesh (read from the
00226    //     file) is not higher order curved mesh compared to the FE space chosen
00227    //     from the menu.
00228    pmesh->SetNodalFESpace(fespace);
00229 
00230    // 13. Save the displaced mesh and the inverted solution (which gives the
00231    //     backward displacements to the original grid). This output can be
00232    //     viewed later using GLVis: "glvis -m displaced.mesh -g sol.gf".
00233    {
00234       GridFunction *nodes = pmesh->GetNodes();
00235       *nodes += x;
00236       x *= -1;
00237       ofstream mesh_ofs;
00238       if (myid == 0)
00239          mesh_ofs.open("displaced.mesh");
00240       mesh_ofs.precision(8);
00241       pmesh->PrintAsOne(mesh_ofs);
00242       if (myid == 0)
00243          mesh_ofs.close();
00244 
00245       ofstream sol_ofs;
00246       if (myid == 0)
00247          sol_ofs.open("sol.gf");
00248       sol_ofs.precision(8);
00249       x.SaveAsOne(sol_ofs);
00250       if (myid == 0)
00251          sol_ofs.close();
00252    }
00253 
00254    // 14. (Optional) Send the above data by socket to a GLVis server. Note that
00255    //     we use "vfem" instead of "fem" in the initial string, to indicate
00256    //     vector grid function. Use the "n" and "b" keys in GLVis to visualize
00257    //     the displacements.
00258    char vishost[] = "localhost";
00259    int  visport   = 19916;
00260    osockstream *sol_sock;
00261    if (myid == 0)
00262    {
00263       sol_sock = new osockstream(visport, vishost);
00264       if (dim == 2)
00265          *sol_sock << "vfem2d_gf_data\n";
00266       else
00267          *sol_sock << "vfem3d_gf_data\n";
00268       sol_sock->precision(8);
00269    }
00270    pmesh->PrintAsOne(*sol_sock);
00271    x.SaveAsOne(*sol_sock);
00272    if (myid == 0)
00273    {
00274       sol_sock->send();
00275       delete sol_sock;
00276    }
00277 
00278    // 15. Free the used memory.
00279    delete pcg;
00280    delete amg;
00281    delete X;
00282    delete B;
00283    delete A;
00284 
00285    delete fespace;
00286    delete fec;
00287 
00288    MPI_Finalize();
00289 
00290    return 0;
00291 }
